title: 1.1.1 Introduction to Python
text: Python is a general purpose, high-level, interpreted programming language developed by Guido van Rossum in the late 1980s at the National Research Institute for Mathematics and Computer Science in the Netherlands. Python is one of the most popular and widely used programming language used for set of tasks including console based, GUI based, web programming and data analysis. Python is an easy to learn and simple programming language so even if you are new to programming, you can learn python without facing any problems. Fact: Python is named after the comedy television show Monty Python's Flying Circus Python Applications Installation of Python

title: 1.1.2 Features of Python
text: Python provides lots of features that are listed below. Simple English-like syntax Ideal for beginners and rapid development. Interpreted Language No compilation required Executes code line-by-line Easier debugging. Cross-platform Language Runs on Windows, Linux, macOS, and Unix Same code works across platforms. Free and Open Source Completely free to download and use Source code can be modified and distributed. GUI Programming Support Create graphical applications using Tkinter, PyQt, etc. Integrated Can be integrated with C, C++, Java, and other languages

title: 1.2.1 Introduction to Conditional Statements
path: Control Flow with Decisions and Loops >  1.2.1 Introduction to Conditional Statements
text: Conditional Statements in Python performs different computations or actions depending on conditions. In python, the following are conditional statements If statement If - else statement if - elif - else statement

title: If statement
path: Control Flow with Decisions and Loops >  If statement
text: The if statement is used to test a specific condition. If the condition is true, a block of code (if-block) will be executed. Syntax: if expression: statement Example: a =33 b =200 if b > a: print("b is greater than a") Output: b is greater than a

title: 1.2.3 If - else statement
path: Control Flow with Decisions and Loops >  1.2.3 If - else statement
text: The if-else statement provides an else block combined with the if statement which is executed in the false case of the condition. If the condition is true, then the if-block is executed. Otherwise, the else-block is executed. Syntax: if expression: #block of statements else: #another block of statements Example: age =int(input("Enter your age : ")) if age >=18: print("You are eligible to vote !!") else: print("Sorry! you have to wait !!") Output: Enter your age:19 You are eligible to vote!!

title: React Introduction
text: ReactJS is a JavaScript library by Facebook for building dynamic, single-page applications. It enables building reusable UI components for easier development and maintenance.

title: Component-Based Architecture
text: UI is divided into small, reusable components, each controlling a specific part of the interface. Improves code reusability, readability, and maintenance.

title: JSX (JavaScript XML)
text: Syntax that lets you write HTML-like code in JavaScript. Easier to design UI components; compiled to regular JavaScript.

title: Virtual DOM
text: Lightweight copy of the real DOM. Updates Virtual DOM first, then applies only necessary changes to the real DOM for better performance.

title: State and Props
text: State: stores component-specific, changeable data. Props: pass data between components. Together, they manage dynamic data flow in the UI.

title: Event Handling
text: Handles user interactions like clicks and typing via event handlers. Events update state, causing dynamic UI updates without page reloads.

title: Overview
text: This chapter introduces the concept of loop statements in Python, which are used to repeat a block of code multiple times. It covers two main types of loops: While Loop: executes as long as a condition remains true. For Loop: iterates over a sequence (like lists, tuples, or strings). The chapter also explains how to use else with loops, nested loops, and practical applications such as printing tables and star patterns.

title: Aim
text: To enable students to understand and implement different types of loop structures in Python for repetitive tasks, and to apply loops in solving real-world programming problems.

title: Requirements
text: Basic understanding of Python syntax and variables. Knowledge of conditional statements. Python interpreter installed IDLE, PyCharm, Jupyter, etc.. Practice problems involving repetitive logic (e.g., printing patterns, traversing sequences).

title: 1.3.1 Introduction to Loop Statements
text: Sometimes we may need to alter the flow of the program. If the execution of a specific code may need to be repeated several numbers of times, then we can go for loop statements. For this purpose, the python provides various types of loops which are capable of repeating some specific code several numbers of times. Those are, while loop for loop

title: 1.3.2 while loop
text: With the while loop we can execute a set of statements as long as a condition is true. The while loop is mostly used in the case where the number of iterations is not known in advance. Syntax: while expression: Statement(s) Example: i=1; while i<=3: print(i); i=i+1; Output: 1 2 3

title: 1.3.3 Using else with while loop
text: Python enables us to use the while loop with the else block also. The else block is executed when the condition given in the while statement becomes false. Syntax: while expression: Statements else: Statements Example: i=1; while i<=3: print(i) i=i+1; else:print("The while loop terminated"); Output: 1 2 3 The while loop terminated

title: 1.3.4 for loop
text: The for loop in Python is used to iterate the statements or a part of the program several times. It is frequently used to traverse the data structures like list, tuple, or dictionary. Syntax: for iterating_var in sequence: statement(s) Example: i=1 n=int(input("Enter n value : ")) for i in range(i,n+1): print(i,end =' ') Output: Enter n value: 5 1 2 3 4 5

title: 1.3.5 Using else with for loop
text: Python allows us to use the else statement with the for loop which can be executed only when all the iterations are exhausted. Here, we must notice that if the loop contains any of the break statement, then the else statement will not be executed. Syntax: for iterating_var in sequence: statements else: statements Example: for i in range(0,5): print(i) else: print("for loop completely exhausted"); Output: 0 1 2 3 4 Note The range() function returns a sequence of numbers, starting from0 by default,and increments by 1(by default),and ends at a specified number. Example: range(6) means the values from0 to 5. range(2,6) means the values from2 to 5. Example Program: Aim: Program to printing the table of the given number Example: i=1; num =int(input("Enter a number:")); for i inrange(1,11): print("%d X %d = %d"%(num,i,num*i)) Output: Enter a number:10 10 X 1=10 10 X 2=20 10 X 3=30 10 X 4=40 10 X 5=50 10 X 6=60 10 X 7=70 10 X 8=80 10 X 9=90 10 X 10=100

title: 1.3.6 Nested for loop in python
text: Python allows us to nest any number of for loops inside a for loop. The inner loop is executed n number of times for every iteration of the outer loop. Syntax: for iterating_var1 in sequence: for iterating_var2 in sequence: #block of statements Example Program: Aim: Program to printing the rows of stars of the given number Example: n =int(input("Enter the no.of rows you want to print : ")) for i inrange(0,n): for j inrange(0,i+1): print("*",end="") print() Output: Enter the no. of rows you want to print:4 * * * * * * * * * *
